USAGE:
　/recordready [subcommand]

>>Subcommands:
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>[countdowntime]<73>01</73><72>01</72>

ALIASES:
　/tell, /t
USAGE:
　/tell [PC name] [message]

→Sends a message to a specific PC within the same World. This message cannot be seen by other PCs, and will not be displayed if [Tell] is deselected in the chat filter. Typing /tell or /t [PC name] without a message switches the default chat mode to [Tell]. Messages can also be sent to PCs on different Worlds provided they are on your friend list. This can be done by including "@World“ after the PC name.

>>Examples:
　/tell [PC name] Hello
　(Sends the message ”Hello“ to
　 [PC name] on your World.)
　/tell [PC name]@Bahamut Hello
　(Sends the message ”Hello“ to
　 [PC name] on the World Bahamut.)

　/waymark, /wmark
USAGE:
　/wmark [marker] “target”

→Place a waymark on the ground below a target. If no target is specified, a waymark will be placed beneath your cursor.

>>Subcommands:
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>a <73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove waymark A. Overwrites existing waymark if target is specified.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>b <73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove waymark B. Overwrites existing waymark if target is specified.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>c <73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove waymark C. Overwrites existing waymark if target is specified.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>d<73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove waymark D. Overwrites existing waymark if target is specified.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>1<73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove waymark 1. Overwrites existing wayrmark if target is specified.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>2<73>01</73><72>01</72> Place or remove wayrmark 2. Overwrites existing waymark if target is specified.
 <72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73> off<73>01</73><72>01</72>/<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>clear <73>01</73><72>01</72> Remove all waymarks.

Places an unused waymark in the order of A-D, 1, 2 when no subcommand is specified. More than six waymarks cannot be placed at one time. If a target name is specified, a marker name must also be specified.

>>Examples:
　/waymark A
　(Places waymark A at the
　selected location.)

　/waymark A <t>
　(Places waymark A at the
　selected target's location.)

USAGE:
　/alarm “name” [clock type] [repeat] [time] [reminder]

>>Clock Type:
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>lt<73>01</73><72>01</72>
　　Set the alarm using local time.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>st<73>01</73><72>01</72>
　　Set the alarm using server time.
　<72>F201FA</72><73>F201FB</73>et<73>01</73><72>01</72>
　　Set the alarm usin Eorzea time.

>>Repeat:
　Use “repeat” or “rp” to set an hourly alarm.

>>Time:
　Times must be set using the 24-hour clock.
　Time values: 0000-2400
　The hour must be omitted when using the repeat subcommand.

>>Reminder:
　A notification can be given up to 60 minutes prior to the alarm.
　Time values: 0-60

The repeat and reminder subcommands can be omitted.
The “clear” subcommand can be used to delete all alarms.
Opens the alarm interface when no subcommands are specified.

>>Examples:
　/alarm Raid lt 2000 10
　(Sets the “Raid” alarm for
　20:00 local time, with a
　notification given 10
　minutes prior.)

　/alarm Party lt rp 30
　(Sets the “Party” alarm as
　an hourly alarm, 30 minutes
　past the hour in local time.)
